0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN11J267	Clinton server technicians decline questions from U.S. Congress	"
By Jonathan Allen
(This Sept. 13 story corrects bureau's name to Federal Bureau of Investigation in paragraph 6
column2: not Federal Bureau of Information)By Jonathan AllenNEW YORK Two computer technicians declined to answer questions from U.S. lawmakers on Tuesday about the unauthorized private email system that Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton used during her tenure as U.S. secretary of state.Paul Combetta and Bill Thornton repeatedly invoked their constitutional right not to incriminate themselves during about 10 minutes of questioning while under oath before the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. A third technician
column3: Bryan Pagliano
column4: declined even to appear
column5: despite a subpoena ordering his testimony.The investigation of Clinton's email system has become a troublesome issue for her presidential campaign
column6: with Republican rival Donald Trump saying a recent finding by federal investigators that she mishandled classified government secrets in her email should disqualify her from office.Brian Fallon
column8: said in a statement it was up to the technicians whether to cooperate
column9: ""but we certainly are not prevailing upon anyone to cooperate with this sham of an inquiry.""Clinton has said she regrets using the system in her New York home's basement for work. Voters have said in surveys the decision contributes to a feeling she is untrustworthy.

column1: Federal Bureau of Investigation director James Comey said in July there was evidence that Clinton and her staff may have broken the law with their ""extremely careless"" handling of classified government secrets
column2: but concluded there were insufficient grounds to prosecute.Combetta and Thornton work for Platte River Networks
column3: the Denver technology firm that managed Clinton's email servers soon after she left the State Department in 2013. They repeatedly invoked their Fifth Amendment protection from self-incrimination to each question from lawmakers. Jason Chaffetz
column4: the committee's Republican chairman
column5: eventually excused them out of what he called ""respect"" for their rights.Elijah Cummings
column6: the committee's most senior Democratic member
column8: saying the Republicans were only trying to use them to embarrass Clinton.

column1: Chaffetz criticized Pagliano
column2: who was paid by Clinton to manage her server while she was the nation's top diplomat
column3: for not complying with the subpoena and said the committee would decide after the hearing whether to punish him. Pagliano was given a form of immunity from prosecution in 2015 for cooperating with the FBI as it looked into the mishandling of classified information over the server
column4: but has otherwise cited the Fifth Amendment in declining to provide information to lawmakers. His attorney did not respond to questions.A fourth witness
column5: Justin Cooper
column6: testified for more than two hours about his role setting up the email system in 2009 while he worked a Clinton family aide.

column1: Clinton used an AT&T email account while a senator and a presidential candidate in 2008. Cooper said there was ""a desire to change her email address because a number of people had received her email address over the course of those activities.""A summary of the FBI's findings showed Combetta saying he used software called BleachBit to delete an archive of Clinton's work emails around the same time as a conference call with Clinton's lawyers
column2: despite lawmakers seeking the records through a subpoena. (Reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Bill Trott and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-obama-refugees-idUSKCN11K08Y	Obama plans to increase number of refugees admitted to U.S.: media	"
The Obama Administration plans to increase the number of refugees admitted to the United States by 30 percent in fiscal year 2017
column2: according to the Wall Street Journal
column3: which cited an annual refugee report submitted to Congress. Secretary of State John Kerry presented the new target of 110
column4: 000 in the 2017 fiscal year starting Oct. 1
column5: up from 85
column7: during a closed session to members of the House and Senate judiciary committees on Tuesday

column1: Kerry has said repeatedly over the past year that the United States would admit at least 100
column2: 000 refugees in fiscal 2017 and try to admit more if it were able.

column1: (Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Milwaukee; Editing by Shri Navaratnam)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-icahn-idUSKCN11J2PD	Icahn says Trump better for U.S. economy than Clinton	"
By Michael Flaherty
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Billionaire investor Carl Icahn continued to throw his support behind the Republican U.S. presidential candidate on Tuesday
column2: saying Donald Trump would reduce the regulation of U.S. companies.Icahn also said that nutrition and weight management company Herbalife would be a strong candidate to go private
column3: saying such a move would allow it to avoid the kind of criticism aimed at it from Pershing Square hedge fund founder William Ackman.""If you look ahead three years
column4: this economy will be a lot better if Trump gets elected"" rather than Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton
column5: Icahn said
column6: speaking at the CNBC ""Delivering Alpha"" event in New York.Trump has said that Icahn would be a great U.S. Treasury secretary though whether the 80-year-old hedge fund manager would commit to such a role remains unclear.

column1: Icahn expressed his frustration at U.S. regulators on Tuesday
column2: specifically the Environmental Protection Agency which he says has neglected to speak to him about his concerns regarding ethanol blending requirements for the fuel refineries in his investment portfolio.Icahn said that fear of ""irrational"" government regulations are a main reason why chief executives are not re-investing in their businesses and instead buying back stock. Trump would aim to reduce such regulations
column3: Icahn said.

column1: Icahn also addressed his ongoing feud with Ackman
column2: who in 2012 claimed Herbalife was running a pyramid scheme
column3: and made a huge wager against the stock. Icahn emerged later as a buyer of the shares.Herbalife settled a probe of its sales practices with the U.S. Federal Trade Commission in July. Icahn has continued buying shares
column4: and the feud with Ackman has continued.

column1: I think that Herbalife is certainly a candidate to go private. In fact
column2: frankly
column3: wearing my shareholder hat
column4: I think Herbalife is a lot better private and getting away from this Ackman-type criticism
column5: Icahn said at the CNBC event. ""Ackman is out there driving everybody crazy
column6: which is his right to do. He's obsessed with this.""An Ackman spokesman did not immediately return an email seeking comment.  (Additional reporting by Lawrence Delevingne; Editing by Phil Berlowitz and Cynthia Osterman)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN11K1UM	Clinton to meet with presidents of Egypt
column2: Ukraine next week: campaign	"

column1: WHITE PLAINS
column2: New York Democratic U.S. presidential candidate Hillary Clinton will meet with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko next week at the United Nations General Assembly
column3: her campaign said on Wednesday.She will also meet with other leaders
column4: the campaign added.

column1: (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Editing by Susan Heavey and Chizu Nomiyama)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-kremlin-obama-idUSKCN11K11M	Kremlin: Obama's Trump criticism anti-Russian
column2: won't foster better ties	"

column1: MOSCOW The Kremlin said on Wednesday it viewed U.S. President Barack Obama's recent statements on Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump as anti-Russian and said they were unlikely to improve fragile relations between Russia and the United States.Obama on Tuesday strongly criticized Trump for praising Russian President Vladimir Putin and for appearing on a TV channel
column2: RT
column3: funded by the Russian government.""Unfortunately
column4: we see continued displays of often hard-core Russophobia
column5: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov
column7: told a conference call with reporters. ""We can only express regret in this regard.

column1: This rhetoric
column2: which is being formulated in electoral campaign style ... is unlikely to help fledgling fragile attempts to build at least some sort of mutual trust.""

column1: (Reporting by Denis Pinchuk; Writing by Dmitry Solovyov; Editing by Andrew Osborn)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN11J1T2	Obama paints Trump as no friend of the working class	"
By Ayesha Rascoe and James Oliphant
| PHILADELPHIA
PHILADELPHIA With Hillary Clinton sidelined by pneumonia
column2: President Barack Obama took up the Democrats' fight against Donald Trump on Tuesday
column3: trying to quash the Republican presidential candidate's bid to appeal to working-class voters.Obama
column4: whose 50 percent job approval rating could help improve the climate for the Democratic ticket in the Nov. 8 election
column5: rallied party faithful against Trump
column6: the 70-year-old New York real estate developer
column7: at an outdoor event in Philadelphia.""This is a guy who spent 70 years on this earth showing no concern for working people. He spent most of his life trying to stay far away from working people. He wasn't going to let you on his golf course
column8: Obama said.Obama's campaign appearance was his first as a solo act on behalf of Clinton as he tries to ensure Democrats retain control of the White House once his eight years are over in January.The president lauded new census numbers on income growth as proof that his administration's policies have helped improve the economy
column9: an attempt to undermine Trump's argument that economic woes are deep.""By so many measures
column10: America is stronger and more prosperous than when we started out on this journey together
column12: who was Obama's secretary of state during his first term
column13: rested at her home in the New York City suburb of Chappaqua
column14: as she recovers from pneumonia. She was diagnosed with pneumonia on Friday but she kept it secret until she nearly collapsed on Sunday at a ceremony in Manhattan marking the Sept. 11
column16: attacks.She is to return to the campaign trail on Thursday
column17: her spokesman Nick Merrill said Tuesday evening.Her campaign said in a statement that she will deliver remarks in Greensboro
column19: on Thursday and ""discuss her vision for an America that is stronger together.""

column1: TRUMP ON CHILD CARE
Trump appeared at a campaign event in suburban Philadelphia after Obama departed
column2: touting proposals that would allow families to deduct child-care expenses from their income taxes and establish paid maternity leave for women whose employers do not offer it. The plan
column3: he said
column4: was aimed to bolster working-class and middle-class families. With his daughter Ivanka at his side
column5: Trump also appeared to support equal pay for women
column6: traditionally a core issue for Democrats.  ""We need working mothers to be fairly compensated for their work and have access to affordable quality child care for their work

column1: As he did earlier in the day at a rally in Des Moines
column2: Trump steered clear of mentioning Clinton's illness but stepped up efforts to wring maximum advantage from her controversial comment that his supporters are ""deplorables."" ""While my opponent slanders you as deplorable and irredeemable
column3: I call you hardworking American patriots who love your country
column4: said Trump
column5: who has tried to portray the former first lady as out of touch with ordinary Americans.Clinton said in a speech last week that half of Trump's supporters belong ""in a basket of deplorables"" and accused them of being racist and homophobic. She later said she regretted the remark.Trump
column6: who has often bragged about his wealth
column7: has come under fire himself for rhetoric against minorities during his campaign
column8: including describing Mexican immigrants as criminals and rapists
column9: suggesting that a judge could not be fair because of his Mexican-American heritage
column10: and proposing a temporary ban on Muslim immigration to the United States.

column1: After struggling in opinion polls in August
column2: Trump has erased most of Clinton's lead in national surveys and is competitive again in many battleground states where the White House race is likely to be decided.    RALLY ARRESTS

column1: The ""deplorables"" comment featured at a Trump rally in Asheville
column2: North Carolina
column3: on Monday night that saw a resumption of some of the violence that disrupted his events earlier this year. ""Never in history has a major party presidential candidate so viciously demonized the American voter
column4: Trump told the crowd. Five people
column5: including a minor
column6: were arrested at the rally and charged with crimes including second degree trespassing and fighting in public
column7: Asheville police said. A man grabbed an anti-Trump protester's neck and punched him during the rally
column8: video from NBC and ABC showed. Police said they also obtained an arrest warrant for the suspect in that incident.  (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson
column9: Eric Walsh and Jeff Mason in Washington and Laila Kearney in New York; Writing by Steve Holland and Susan Heavey; Editing by Alistair Bell and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-briton-idUSKCN11K00W	Briton pleads guilty to weapons charge over Trump rally incident	"
By Curtis Skinner

A British tourist who caused a security scare at a Donald Trump campaign rally in Las Vegas in June by trying to grab a gun from a police officer pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges of illegal weapon possession and disorderly conduct
column2: court papers showed.Michael Steven Sandford
column4: admitted as part of his plea deal with prosecutors that he had approached a policeman at the event
column5: saying he wanted an autograph from the presidential candidate
column6: then tried to pull the officer's gun from his holster with both hands
column8: who had by then overstayed his tourist visa by about 10 months
column9: was immediately arrested and removed from the rally.He also acknowledged having visited a Las Vegas gun range the day before the June 18 incident at the Treasure Island casino-hotel
column10: to take shooting lessons with a rented Glock handgun
column11: firing 20 rounds at a paper target

column1: No mention was made in the plea agreement about whether Sandford intended to harm Trump
column2: then the presumptive Republican nominee in the U.S. presidential race. In the initial June 20 criminal complaint stemming from the incident
column3: prosecutors said Sandford had told a U.S. Secret Service agent he had driven to Las Vegas from California with the aim of shooting Trump.

column1: On June 29
column2: Sandford was charged with felony counts of being an illegal alien in possession of a firearm and disrupting government business
column3: but he was not accused of plotting to kill Trump. At Tuesday's hearing in federal court in Las Vegas
column4: Sandford pleaded guilty to those two charges
column5: each of which carry a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $250
column7: the U.S. Attorney's Office said in a statement. Sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 13.

column1: Brenda Weksler
column2: one of Sandford's federal public defenders
column3: declined to comment. (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Steve Gorman and Richard Chang)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-campaigning-idUSKCN11J2S5	Clinton to resume campaigning on Thursday
column2: 'details to come'	"

column1: WHITE PLAINS
column2: N.Y. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column3: who is recuperating from pneumonia
column4: plans to resume campaigning on Thursday
column5: her spokesman said.Clinton ""has spent the day catching up on reading briefings
column6: making calls"" and watching on television President Barrack Obama's speech at a campaign appearance for the former secretary of state in Philadelphia
column7: spokesman Nick Merrill said on Tuesday.""We will resume campaign travel on Thursday

column1: Hours after Clinton
column3: almost collapsed on Sunday at a New York memorial ceremony for the Sept. 11
column5: attacks
column6: her doctor said she had been diagnosed with pneumonia two days earlier.Clinton said on Monday that she would rest a few days before resuming her campaign for the Nov. 8 election against Republican Donald Trump.

column1: Clinton said she had ignored doctor's order to rest and had not revealed her diagnosis earlier because ""I just didn't think it was going to be that big a deal.""
(Reporting by Amanda Becker; Writing by Mohammad Zargham; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-tennessee-lawmaker-idUSKCN11J2T0	Tennessee lawmaker ousted after sex harassment allegations: media	"
NASHVILLE A Tennessee lawmaker was expelled from the state's House of Representatives on Tuesday following accusations of widespread sexual harassment
column2: media reported. Republican state Representative Jeremy Durham was ousted by a vote of 70-2
column3: according to the Tennessean newspaper
column4: which said this was the state's first legislative expulsion since 1980. Durham did not immediately respond to request for comment. The Tennessean reported that Durham said no formal complaint had been filed against him and that he has not been charged with a crime. ""I'm very pleased that the House made the decision it did today. This was good for the taxpayers of the state. It was good for the victims of the state
column5: the newspaper quoted House Speaker Beth Harwell as saying.

column1: A spokeswoman for Harwell's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment. A report released by Tennessee's attorney general in July accused Durham of inappropriate sexual conduct with 22 women over a four-year period. The report said Durham repeatedly made unwelcome sexual advances toward female legislative staff
column2: interns and lobbyists.

column1: Durham declined to be interviewed by investigators
column2: the report said. His lawyer
column3: Bill Harbison
column4: said at the time that the report was politically motivated and unfair.Harbison could not be immediately reached for comment on Tuesday.

column1: The chairman of Tennessee's Republican Party
column2: Ryan Haynes
column3: said on Tuesday: ""I am saddened that all of my former colleagues
column4: both Republicans and Democrats
column5: have been placed in this terrible position by the reprehensible misbehavior of one individual.""   (Reporting by Tim Ghianni in Nashville and Timothy Mclaughlin in Chicago; Writing by Timothy Mclaughlin; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-tampon-idUSKCN11J2QK	California governor vetoes bill to repeal tampon tax	"
By Sharon Bernstein
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif.

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. California Governor Jerry Brown on Tuesday vetoed a bill to end state sales taxes on feminine hygiene products
column3: angering women and advocates who call the taxes unjust.Brown
column4: a Democrat
column5: cited imperatives of fiscal restraint and viable revenue streams in blocking the bipartisan bill
column7: sanitary napkins and other menstrual products to a list of necessities such as food and prescription medicines that are exempt from sales tax.Brown also vetoed several similar bills that would have ended certain state taxes for diapers and other items. He said those measures
column8: together with repeal of the tax on feminine hygiene products
column9: would collectively reduce state revenue by $300 million through the coming year.""Each of these bills creates a new tax break or expands an existing tax break
column10: Brown said in a statement. ""As I said last year
column11: tax breaks are the same as new spending - they both cost the general fund money.""

column1: State Assemblywoman Cristina Garcia
column2: chief sponsor of the tampon tax relief bill that passed both houses of the state legislature with unanimous support
column3: railed against the veto in a posting on Facebook.""Jerry Brown please #mansplain why it's OK to balance the budget on women's backs?"" she wrote
column4: including a slang portmanteau of ""man"" and ""explain"" that is used to disparage men who talk to women in a manner regarded as condescending or patronizing.

column1: Lawmakers in at least 15 states have introduced measures to abolish their sales taxes on menstrual products. New York repealed its tampon tax in June
column2: joining Maryland
column3: Massachusetts
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: Minnesota and New Jersey.The movement appeals to Republicans because it would repeal a tax and is favored by Democrats
column6: who say it eliminates an unfair burden on women

column1: Garcia
column2: the California assemblywoman
column3: said she would press on in seeking repeal
column4: vowing to ""keep pushing until we get it done."" But it was not immediately clear whether a veto override bid was an option.Overriding a veto in California requires a two-thirds vote in both the state Senate and Assembly
column5: and the legislative session ended Aug. 31.  (Writing and additional reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Steve Gorman and Matthew Lewis)"
